inlineContent.text: Autocomplete is an important part of the typing experience, where word suggestions can be presented in a toolbar above the keyboard as the user types, and incorrectly text can be autocorrected.
In KeyboardKit, an
can provide suggestions and predictions to the main
. Unlike other services, there is no standard autocomplete service in the open-source SDK.
ðŸ‘‘
unlocks a
and a
, next character prediction, next word prediction, etc. Information about Pro features can be found further down.
KeyboardKit has an
namespace with autocomplete-related types, like a
model, a
view, etc.
KeyboardKit has an
that provides observable autocomplete state, and auto-persisted
that can be used to customize the autocomplete behavior.
KeyboardKit automatically creates an instance of this class, injects it into
and updates it whenever autocomplete is performed.
In KeyboardKit, an
can provide suggestions when the user types and the text input cursor moves in the text.
KeyboardKit doesnâ€™t have a standard autocomplete service, as it has for other service types. Instead, it injects a
service into
until you set up
or inject your own service implementation.
KeyboardKit has an
type with autocomplete-related settings. The context
is used by default.
The
namespace has autocomplete-specific views, that can be used to mimic native autocomplete toolbars and items.
The autocomplete
can be used to show autocomplete suggestions as the user types.
The view can be styled with a
, which is applied with the
modifier. It can also use completely custom views.
This view is used as the standard toolbar by the
. You can style it with a global style modifier.
unlocks a
and a
, and injects a local service into
when you set up KeyboardKit Pro. You can inherit both classes to customize their functionality.
KeyboardKit Pro also unlocks an
engine that can be used to add emoji suggestions to the autocomplete result, as well as next character prediction and next word prediction.
The
performs on-device autocomplete. It works offline, doesnâ€™t require Full Access, integrates with system services like the local lexicon, and supports the following languages:

Arabic, Arabic, Najdi, Bulgarian (Bulgaria), Czech (Czechia), Danish (Denmark), Dutch (Netherlands), English (Australia), English (Canada), English (India), English (New Zealand), English (Singapore), English (South Africa), English (United Kingdom), English (United States), Finnish (Finland), French (France), German (Germany), Greek (Greece), Hebrew (Israel), Hindi, Hungarian (Hungary), Icelandic (Iceland), Indonesian (Indonesia), Irish (Ireland), Italian (Italy), Lithuanian (Lithuania), Norwegian BokmÃ¥l (Norway), Norwegian Nynorsk, Polish (Poland), Portuguese (Brazil), Portuguese (Portugal), Punjabi, Romanian (Romania), Russian (Russia), Slovenian (Slovenia), Spanish (Mexico), Spanish (Spain), Swedish (Sweden), Telugu, Turkish (TÃ¼rkiye), Ukrainian (Ukraine), Vietnamese (Vietnam)

Arabic, Arabic, Najdi, Bulgarian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, English, English (Australia), English (Canada), English (India), English (Japan), English (New Zealand), English (Singapore), English (South Africa), English (United Kingdom), Finnish, French, German, Greek, Hebrew, Hindi, Hungarian, Icelandic, Indonesian, Irish, Italian, Korean, Lithuanian, Norwegian BokmÃ¥l, Norwegian Nynorsk, Polish, Portuguese (Brazil), Portuguese (Portugal), Punjabi, Romanian, Russian, Slovenian, Spanish, Swedish, Telugu, Turkish, Ukrainian, Vietnamese
The service will use perform emoji autocomplete if
is enabled. You can also inject a
to make the service perform next word predictions with an external AI service.
The
can be used to perform autocomplete by integrating with any external API. It requires that the device is online, and requires Full Access to be able to make network requests.
You create a remote autocomplete service by defining the API URL, any potential headers or query parameters, as well as a result type.
Autocomplete suggestions with a
type are only applied if the user taps on them, while suggestions with the
type will be automatically applied when the user taps on a word delimiter, like space.
The
will try its best to provide proper autocorrections, but sometimes it will fail to do so. If so, you can add custom values to the
dictionary.
The
and
perform next-character predictions on their results.
This information is used by
to slightly increase the tap area of more probable keys, to reduce the risk of typing error.

Appleâ€™s native text prediction utilities stopped supporting next word prediction in iOS 16. It instead only provides predictions on already typed text, without any (known) way to get next word predictions.
KeyboardKit Pro therefore unlocks ways to perform next word prediction via 3rd party AI services. The easiest way to enable next word prediction, is to add a Claude- or OpenAI-based
to your
You can use these pre-defined requests to integrate with Claude or OpenAI, by providing an API key and any optional customizations:
You can also let your users select which next word prediction request to use, with their own private API key. Read more further down.

AI-based next word prediction requires Full Access. Itâ€™s disabled by default, to avoid sending typed text to 3rd parties without the userâ€™s explicit consent. When a user has given its explicit content, you can enable it with
You can let your users use their own next word prediction integrations, use their own API key and pay for their own data consumption.
Just give your users a way to define a
and a
will then provide you with a properly configured
for that information.
KeyboardKit Proâ€™s
has a visibility setting to show a next word prediction section. This section is hidden by default.
The
will automatically call
whenever the keyboard text changes, or the input cursor is moved, after which it updates the
with the
result.
You can configure the
, override the
â€™s autocomplete properties and functions, and replace the
with a custom service, to customize the autocomplete behavior.
The
automatically adds an autocomplete
to list
and provide extra top space for callouts.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks an emoji
engine that makes it possible to search for emojis by starting the current word with a colon. This is automatically used by
when
is true.
You can create a custom autocomplete service to customize the autocomplete behavior or integrate with 3rd party services. You can the implement
protocol from scratch, or inherit and customize any
service:
To use this service instead of the standard one, just inject it into
by replacing its
property:
This will make KeyboardKit use your custom autocomplete service instead of the standard one.

abstract.text: This article describes the KeyboardKit autocomplete engine.
An autocorrect suggestion is applied when a user
types a word or sentence delimiter.
This is the input controller to use in KeyboardKit-based
keyboard extensions.
Perform an autocomplete operation.
This struct provides a dictionary with
This type can be used to define important properties for
your app, and is also a namespace for app-based features.
This article describes how KeyboardKit Pro can identify and use the host application.
A custom, user-specified next word predicton request type.
This article describes the KeyboardKit action engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit input engine.
A regular suggestion is applied when itâ€™s tapped.
The suggestions that should be presented to the user,
which is an aggregate of the
This style can be used to modify the visual style of
the
component.
This namespace contains autocomplete-related types.
This article describes the KeyboardKit feedback engine.
Try to build a next word prediction request from the
selected request type and provided API key, if any.
Whether emoji autocomplete is enabled, by default
This class has observable states and persistent settings
for keyboard autocomplete.
This protocol can be implemented by any type that can be
used perform autocomplete as the user types.
This article describes the KeyboardKit AI support capabilities.
Create an OpenAI-based next word prediction request.
This article describes the KeyboardKit device utilities.
This article describes the KeyboardKit emoji engine.
The autocomplete service to use.
This service can perform on-device autocomplete, and
also perform additional operations and predictions.
This article describes the KeyboardKit navigation engine.
This article describes the KeyboardKit layout engine.
This toolbar can be added above the keyboard to show
autocomplete suggestions as the user types.
This type can be used to enable next word prediction.
KeyboardKit helps you create fully customizable keyboard extensions, using Swift and SwiftUI.
This article describes the KeyboardKit app-specific utilities.
Whether next word prediction is enabled, by default
This dictionary can be used to define autocorrection
replacements for various locales.
The suggestions that were returned by the service.

This article describes the KeyboardKit localization engine.
This view can be used to mimic a native iOS keyboard.

This screen can be used as a main settings screen in
a keyboard app or its keyboard extension.
This article describes the KeyboardKit callout engine.
The autocomplete context to use.

by calling any REST-based API.
